üì¢ ATTENTION ‚Äî FED DECISION TODAY AND IMPACT ON THE CRYPTO MARKET

Today, the official FED decision on interest rates takes place, and this is one of the most important macroeconomic events of the year for all markets ‚Äî including crypto.

Over the past few weeks, much of the market instability we‚Äôve seen came precisely from expectations surrounding this decision.
When the market is uncertain about interest rates, capital moves into caution mode, volatility increases, and risk assets feel the direct impact.

‚úÖ If there is any signal of a rate cut, the effect tends to be positive:
more liquidity, higher risk appetite, and stronger capital flow into assets like Bitcoin, altcoins, and tokens such as EXD.

‚ùå If the stance remains restrictive, the market may continue under pressure in the short term.

Today‚Äôs decision is especially important because it will define the tone for the year‚Äôs close and the beginning of the next market cycle.

We are closely monitoring the official announcement and, as soon as the FED statement is released, we will bring a direct analysis to the community.

#FED #CRYPTO #Today #CryptoMatket

Will Bitcoin Pump or Dump after today‚Äôs FOMC rate cut ?   The last four times the Fed cut rates by 25 bps, $BTC  saw a 5‚Äì10% dump in the days after.  But this time the setup is different. Positives  - QT has finally ended after 3 years. If Powell even hints at QE in today‚Äôs speech, it could be very bullish.  - This is the 3rd rate cut, which means more liquidity can start flowing back into the market. That usually helps risk assets like Bitcoin pump.  Negatives  - MSCI‚Äôs decision on January 15 is important. If they remove MSTR from their global index, Bitcoin can dump hard.  - Japan‚Äôs rate decision is on December 19. They‚Äôre likely to hike by 25 bps, and historically when Japan hikes, Bitcoin often sees a big dump. Ôªø#BTC Price Analysis#  #Macro Insights#  #Altcoin Season#

Bitcoin is trading around $92,200 ‚Äî what happens after the Fed decision?   With the FOMC interest rate announcement coming in today at 19:00 UTC, the market is entering a classic ‚Äúcalm before the storm‚Äù phase. $BTC   is holding above the $92K level, but volatility could expand within minutes of the decision.   If the Fed signals softer inflation and future rate cuts: ‚Äì Liquidity conditions may improve ‚Äì Risk appetite could return ‚Äì BTC could attempt another push toward higher ranges   If the tone is more hawkish: ‚Äì Dollar strength may increase ‚Äì Risk assets could face short-term pressure ‚Äì BTC might retest lower support zones   For now, traders are watching the Fed‚Äôs wording more than the number itself. No matter the outcome, volatility is almost guaranteed ‚Äî manage risk carefully and stay adaptive. #BTC

#SilkRoad  Wallets Move $3M After Decade Dormant, Arkham Reports  Over 170 cryptocurrency addresses associated with the defunct Silk Road marketplace executed transfers totaling $3.14 million in $BTC  on Tuesday, marking their first significant activity in five years. The movement occurred less than one year after President Trump pardoned the marketplace's founder Ross Ulbricht, who had been serving life sentences.  Blockchain analytics firm #Arkham  tracked 176 transactions flowing from Silk Road-tagged wallets into a single unidentified address labeled bc1qn. The sending wallets retain approximately $38.4 million in $BTC , while the receiving address now holds only the newly transferred funds.  Prior to Tuesday's activity, these wallets had executed just three small test transactions throughout 2025. The timing and purpose of the large-scale movement remain unexplained, with Ulbricht not responding to inquiries about the transfers or wallet control.

You can do a 50-50 split, but I personally go for a 70-30 strategy‚Äî70% Bitcoin, 30% gold‚Äîbecause Bitcoin is ultimately a stronger growth asset. Gold provides balance and risk coverage, while Bitcoin drives most of the upside.

Bitcoin is, in my view, the cornerstone of the crypto market. Many sell out of fear, but hedging with gold helps you manage risk while staying in the game.

The Federal Reserve just issued its third 25bps rate cut of the year ‚Äî bringing the benchmark rate down to 3.50%‚Äì3.75%, the lowest level in years.

The Fed cited elevated uncertainty, softer hiring, and rising downside risks to employment as key factors in the decision. October‚Äôs data showed job openings rising slightly to 7.67M, but hiring falling sharply by 218,000 ‚Äî a combination that signals cooling momentum.

What‚Äôs raising eyebrows is that inflation data is now delayed until January after Trump postponed its release for the first time in over a decade. That left policymakers making a major rate decision without current CPI numbers, something several Fed members and economists openly worried about.

Markets reacted instantly:
‚Ä¢ Dow +230 points
‚Ä¢ S&P 500 and Russell also moved higher
‚Ä¢ Fed‚Äôs new 2025 Summary of Economic Projections points to one rate cut in 2026, unchanged from September‚Äôs outlook

Notably, three Fed officials dissented, including Stephen Miran ‚Äî favored by Trump ‚Äî who argued for a sharper 50bps cut.


This cut signals a Fed leaning more toward protecting the labor market than fighting inflation right now. But with incomplete data and political pressure in the background, the path ahead feels less predictable than usual. Markets like it in the short term ‚Äî but clarity on inflation will decide how durable this move is.

But as a trader I follow the chart not sentiments or hype.  Looking at what the chart is saying Bitcoin ( $BTC  ) will not hold these gains because a bear flag structure is developing.   Price is currently forming a textbook bear flag, characterized by: - A strong impulsive move down (flagpole) - A controlled, low volume corrective grind upward (flag) - Gradually weakening momentum as we approach resistance  The grey zone on the chart is my preferred area to scale into shorts. The Bitcoin community, like many cryptocurrency spaces, has seen its share of mass hysteria, often fueled by influencers, social media hype, and speculative trading. 

While Bitcoin itself is based on a robust technological foundation, the community around it can sometimes fall into a collective mindset that overlooks sound investment strategies in favor of greed and fear of missing out (FOMO). 

This leads many retail investors to hold on too long, driven by the idea that the price will continue to rise indefinitely.

When the market inevitably corrects, these investors are left with losses, often exacerbated by the pressure of the hype. 

It's important to remember that the crypto space, like the collapse of OneCoin or Terra Luna, has seen many spectacular crashes where mass hysteria and influencer-led FOMO contributed to the downfall.

Retail investors must understand that taking profits when the market is at a peak is a smart strategy, rather than holding out for an unrealistic "moon" price.

Ultimately, investing should always be based on research, sound decision-making, and risk management
not on the highs of mass euphoria or the fear of missing out. 

Don't FOMO, 
Don't HOdl.
Take profit.

The Fed delivered the expected 25bps rate cut yesterday, bringing the funds rate to 3.50%-3.75% wh ch is the third cut this year. Markets front-ran it hard, with Bitcoin pushing toward $94k-$95k in the days before on hopes of easier money boosting risk assets like crypto.  But today, we're seeing a classic "sell the news" reaction. $BTC  is down around 2-2.5%, trading near $90k-$92k, and ETH is off over 3-4%. The cut was fully priced in (over 90% odds), so no big surprise there. What spooked traders was Powell's press conference, he sounded pretty cautious. Inflation is still sticky above 2%, the job market is softening but not crashing, and the new dot plot shows only one more cut projected for all of 2026 (down from earlier hopes of more). Some Fed members even dissented, wanting to pause already.  Short term, this hawkish vibe is weighing on stocks and crypto alike. Risk appetite is cooling, with tech dragging and AI worries adding pressure. We could see BTC retrace further to $88k or even low $80ks if sentiment stays weak, similar quick 5-10% dips happened right after the September and October cuts.  Longer term, the picture is still positive. Lower rates overall make holding cash less attractive, and with no hikes on the horizon, liquidity should support crypto over time. Institutional ETF flows remain steady, and dips like this have been bought aggressively in past cycles, leading to higher grinds (think post-cut rallies earlier this year). Many analysts still eye $100k by year-end if we stabilize.  If you're holding, expect some chop and maybe tighten stops around $88k-$90k. If waiting on the sidelines, these pullbacks could be good entry spots for the bigger upside. FOMC reactions are always volatile, don't FOMO chase the top or panic sell the dip. Stay patient!
